title: Is Batman a superhero? Britain's toughest job interview questions revealed
text:
Is Batman a superhero? Britain's toughest job interview questions revealed Is Batman a superhero? Britain's toughest job interview questions revealed JOB seekers in Britain are facing more rigorous and lengthier hiring processes with ever tougher lines of questioning, according to research. PUBLISHED: 18:15, Wed, Jul 1, 2015 | UPDATED: 18:41, Wed, Jul 1, 2015 GETTY Job interviews are tougher and taking longer 
The average job interview now takes 28.6 days to complete - almost double the 14 days it took in 2010. Candidates are now more likely to have to take drug tests and agree to detailed background checks by prospective employers. And the increased level of screening is pushing up hiring times, , according to research by recruitment website Glassdoor.Overall the Government tends to be the slowest at recruiting, whereas retail and fast food outlets were among the fastest, it was found. Companies are also striving to find the best people to fill jobs thorugh increasingly bizarre lines of questioning. Related articles Britain's heatwave: How hot can it get before your boss has to... 
The leftfield questions are typically designed to catch an applicant off guard and produce an answer that has not been pre-prepared. Usually an employer is not looking for a 'right' answer but studying how the candidate reacts when faced with a problem. Glassdoor has now compiled a list of the hardest interview questions anonymously submitted through its website by UK candidates. 1. “Can you calculate how many tennis balls are used during the course of Wimbledon?” – Asked by Accenture to an analyst candidate. 2. “Estimate the total number of cars in the UK.” – Asked by Barclays Capital to a trading analyst candidate. 3. “How many calories are in a grocery store?” – Asked by Google to a product manager candidate. 4. “How would you sell a fridge to an Eskimo?” – Asked by Harrods to a temporary sales associate candidate. 5. “What would you take to a lonely island with you and why?” – Asked by Urban Outfitters to a sales assistant candidate. 6. “Is Batman a superhero?” – Asked by AlphaSights to a support engineer candidate. 7. “You have 17 red and 17 blue balls, and you remove two at a time. If the two are the same colour, add in one extra blue ball. If they are different colours, add in an extra red ball. What colour is the final ball removed?” – Asked by Geonomics to a software engineer candidate. 8. “What cartoon character would you be and why?” – Asked by ASDA to a administrative assistant candidate. 9. “What is the wildest thing that you have done?” – Asked by Metro Bank to a teller candidate. 10. “What was your opinion of the film Blair Witch Project?” – Asked by Jefferies & Company to a data analyst candidate.
